title: Elliott wins world fair play award
description: Herb Elliott, one of Australia's greatest athletes, has won a world fair play award almost 50 years after he became an Olympic champion, the Australian Olympic Committee said.
cleaned_text: Elliott wins world fair play award Herb Elliott, one of Australia's greatest athletes, has won a world fair play award almost 50 years after he became an Olympic champion, the Australian Olympic Committee said. The International Committee for Fair Play (CIFP), based in Hungary, awarded Elliott its top honour, the Jean Borotra World Fair Play Trophy, named after the founder of the organisation, it said. One of the world's great all-time milers, Elliott smashed his own world record in winning gold in the 1,500 metres at the 1960 Rome Olympics. Elliott, 69, said he was surprised and honoured to receive recognition so long after his retirement from competitive running. "Sport teaches young people strong lessons, discipline, respect for rules and teamwork," Elliott said in an AOC statement. "None of this works if participants aren't fair in their dealings with competitors and their sport. So no matter how long ago I performed, I feel very honoured to receive this recognition." During his career Elliott was unbeaten in world class events over the mile and 1,500 metres, winning 44 consecutive races. He broke the four-minute mile on 17 occasions. His winning time in Rome was good enough to take the gold medal in Seoul 1988, Barcelona 1992 and Atlanta 1996. Elliott continued to be a high achiever in business, running a large sportswear company in Australia and North America. He was one of the bearers of the Olympic torch at the opening ceremony of the 2000 Sydney Olympics, entering the stadium for the final segment before the lighting of the Olympic flame. In nominating Elliott for the Fair Play award, AOC secretary-general Craig Phillips wrote: "Herb's mentorship of young athletes has been exemplary. He has steadfastly promoted a commitment to excellence, both in sport and in life." In 2002, he was awarded the Companion of the Order of Australia (AC) for service to community leadership through the development of sport in Australia.
